Award.AwardTitle: Career Education in Renewable Energy Technology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Madison Area Technical College (MATC), in collaboration with the Consortium for Education in Renewable Energy Technology (CERET), offers Train the Trainer Academies for high school and two-year college instructors in renewable energy technologies, and Renewable Energy Certificates to students through online and face-to-face courses. This project strengthens and expands the current model by developing new professional development offerings and certificates in both bioenergy and advanced solar photovoltaics. The primary project goal is to provide renewable energy expertise to two-year college and high school instructors around the country, while creating model career pathways that give students broad skill sets and flexibility in tough and unpredictable labor markets. New courses and certificates in second and third generation biofuels and advanced solar photovoltaics will be the primary products of this effort.

This three-year project addresses a critical need for community college and high school faculty professional development in renewable energy technologies to meet the growing student interest and demand for training in these job growth areas. Participating faculty enhance their content knowledge and skills related to renewable energy technology through hands-on training. As part of the biofuels training, participants learn about second and third generation biofuels, produce biodiesel fuel, perform tests on fuel samples, measure emissions on petroleum and biofuels and discuss and share techniques for teaching about biofuels. In the Advanced Photovoltaics Academy, participants practice installation, inspections, trouble-shooting, repair, and decommissioning of solar electric systems. Concurrent development of new, renewable energy certificates in these two areas provides current students the opportunity to specialize in renewable energy within traditional employment fields and provides incumbent workers in a variety of technical fields the opportunity to retool and become more competitive in green energy occupations.

To enhance the impact of the Train the Trainer model, the project targets faculty from campuses that lack the resources for professional development such as: from small institutions, from remote geographic areas, and from schools that serve minorities, economically disadvantaged, and other underrepresented groups. Communication and collaboration between high school and two-year college faculty participating in the Academies, in turn, helps to build career pathways for students as they transition from high school to college to the workforce.

This faculty professional development model and certificate program helps to meet the growing demand for renewable energy technicians in the biofuel and solar electric industries. The new courses and associated materials are available through CERET and other renewable energy organizations so that other schools can cultivate renewable energy courses on their campuses, even during lean budget years.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The mission of the Career Education in Renewable Energy Technology (CERET) project was to increase the availability and use of renewable energy.  The goal of the project was to provide renewable energy expertise to two-year college and high school instructors around the country, while creating model career pathways.

The project was conceived with two key objectives:

Objective 1:  Broaden the popular CERET Train the Trainer Academies to serve a larger number of teachers from diverse schools.

Objective 2:  Evolve Madison College’s existing Renewable Energy Certificate into independent academic credentials focusing on solar electricity, wind, and bioenergy in response to national trends and regional needs.  

 

Outcomes for Objective 1:

CERET created and delivered Renewable Energy Train the Trainers Academies that featured team-taught instruction pairing veteran renewable energy professionals with experienced classroom instructors to offer both technical and pedagogical expertise.  The academies were offered during summer to meet teacher schedules, and graduate credit was awarded to facilitate professional recognition and advancement. 

The CERET Renewable Energy Academies served at total of 284 teachers, from 39 different states, plus participants from the U.S. territories of Guam, Puerto Rico, and the Virgin Islands.  The academies included a mix of two-year college and high school instructors, which helped build educational understanding and foster the creation of academic pathways between institutions. The academies attracted several faculty participant teams, including groups from Delaware, Maine, Michigan, Missouri, New Mexico, New York, North Carolina, South Carolina, Virginia, Washington, and Wisconsin.  The academies also included participants from three Native American Tribal Colleges, several Hispanic Serving Institutions, and one Historically Black College and University.  It is also notable that this project reached a large number of women in the STEM fields.  

The results of the Renewable Energy Academies were impressive. On evaluations, 96% of the participants indicated that their interest in renewable energy increased as a result of the academy. Pre- and post-test scores also indicated significant increases in renewable energy content knowledge for academy participants.  The Pre- and post- test results were consistent with self-assessed knowledge gains, which reflected that the academy participants were actively aware of their own learning (Walz and Shoemaker, 2017).

In 2015, Madison College launched the inaugural Wisconsin STEM Educator Solar Institute, targeting high school teachers. The Wisconsin Solar Academy was modeled on previous Train the Trainer Academies, combined with instructional best practices from the Wisconsin K-12 Energy Education Program. The content was modified to specifically target high school STEM educators, and to align instructional activities with Wisconsin state educational standards.  By the end of summer 2017, a total of 47 high school teachers will have participated in the Wisconsin Solar Institute.  The Institute serves as a model outreach and recruitment platform, fostering interaction between two-year college renewable energy programs and high schools in their service district.  College instructors from the states of Colorado, Maine, Oregon, and Washington have participated in the Solar Institute, and are currently planning to replicate this activity in their own states.

 

Outcomes for Objective 2:

Madison College's Renewable Energy Certificate is the largest certificate that the College has ever offered.  Over 580 students have enrolled in renewable energy courses, including individuals from 45 different states, three U.S. Territories, the District of Columbia, Canada, Egypt, Estonia, Grand Cayman, Haiti, Israel, the Philippines, South Africa, St. Lucia, Trinidad, and the United Arab Emirates.

This grant project built upon the original certificate model to create three new technology-specific certificates in Photovoltaics, Wind, and Bioenergy.  Over a dozen new renewable energy courses were created to support the certificates. The Renewable Energy Certificates have since been viewed by many as national models to integrate renewable energy technology with education in traditional STEM related academic fields.

As of the conclusion of this project, over 50 students have earned some type of renewable energy certificate from Madison College. There are also over forty active students at Madison College who were taking coursework in one or more of these areas.  Of those students, about one-fifth are Female, 73% are White, 4% Black, 2% Hispanic, 2% Asian, and 19% Multiracial.   

 

References

K.A. Walz, and J.B. Shoemaker.  Preparing the Future Sustainable Energy Workforce and The Center for Renewable Energy Advanced Technological Education.  The Journal of Sustainability Education Vol 17, March (2017)
